Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research is comprised of three areas: (a) harvesting piezoelectric energy from beam structure flutter in air flow, (b) Palatal Flutter Model for Snoring/Apnea and (c) unobtrusive Wind Flow Monitoring by Laser Scintillation. The proposed method will be validated by wind tunnel testing.

Intellectual Merit

This work makes original contributions to: (a) the Continuum Theory of Axial as well as Normal Fluid Flow over a Structure such as a thin Beam: the Flutter speed and LCO amplitude (b) optimization theory for cantilever beam parameters to maximize the output power generated by the piezoelectric strips spanning the beam structure in Flutter (c) derivation of the Laser scintillation diode detector output zero crossing rate due to crosswind.

Broader Impact

The potential impact of includes the development of renewable energy methods based on harvesting piezoelectric energy from aeroelastic flutter. The proposed work has potential to provide quantitative understanding of Snoring/Apnea as aeroelastic flutter of the soft palate and possible means of remedy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Project Outcome Report - 1128693

Equipment was procured, installed and used for the experimental investigation of a wind powered piezoelectric energy harvester. The experimental effort consisted of two main parts:

  1. Determination of natural frequencies, or mode frequencies, of beams with and without piezoelectric patches.
  2. Wind tunnel experiments to determine flutter speed and Limit Cycle Oscillation (LCO) characteristics of beam in axial flow.

The work described in Item 1 is fundamental to the investigation of the Fluid Structure Interaction (FSI) of the system because it provides important information about the dynamics of the structure. More specifically, how adding piezoelectric patches to the beam affects its natural frequencies was determined. Over the course of this project, multiple approaches were developed to accomplish this and the methods have improved over time. The latest technique is using an automated impact hammer to excite higher frequency modes and ensure repeatability of the excitation source. Although this project has ended, the experimental work it is based on will continue in support of the NSF grant that involves the theoretical modeling of the system (NSF Grant #1307990).

Item 2 listed above involves the experimental determination of the flutter speed of the beam and the observation of the LCO characteristics using high speed cameras. We have obtained the flutter speed of various beam configurations and have used the high speed cameras to record the beam’s motion while it is in LCO, but the image processing techniques employed thus far have been elementary. Investigation into more advanced image processing methods will continue in support of the NSF grant that involves the theoretical modeling of the system (NSF Grant #1307990).


Last Modified: 08/07/2015
Modified by: A V Balakrishnan
